Award.AwardTitle: BECS: Collaborative Research: Dynamical Networks and Collective Synchronization of Coupled Lasers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to conduct rigorous mathematical analysis of complex networks of interconnected dynamical systems, and apply the developed methods to control and collectively synchronize arrays of coupled semiconductor lasers. The main idea is based on the dynamical, rather than traditional static, description of the topology of a network, which allows to account for an analysis and evaluation of cumulative action of all three major ingredients that form a dynamical network: 1. local dynamics of elements of the network, 2. interactions between the elements of a network, 3. topology of the network. The project seeks an integration of the mathematical foundations with real world applications, and the developed mathematical machinery will be used to find synchronization conditions and to choose control parameters for synchronization of arrays of coupled semiconductor lasers.

The project will advance the fields of complex dynamical networks, nonlinear dynamics, and coupled semiconductor lasers, and provide theoretical guidance for laser experiments that may lead to significant technological impact in applications of semiconductor lasers such as space, fiber, and underwater communication, welding, cutting and others. The project integrates research projects with education activities through undergraduate and graduate education and research training, short course and workshop development, and outreach to K-12 education. The team also plans to recruit women engineering students and to retain them into careers in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A firm mathematical background for analysis of dynamical networks has been created. This mathematical theory is based on a new approach to analysis of dynamical networks and contains quite a few theorems (i.e. rigorously proven results). Each dynamical network consists of network 's elements, interactions between elements and topology (graph of interactions between networks elements). The first two features (individual dynamics of elements and interactions between them ) are dynamical systems by themselves. Therefore they can be easily and naturally treated together. However a static topology of a networks looks like an apple between these two oranges. Our approach allowed to naturally represent a topology of a network as yet another (third) dynamical system and thus transform this apple into the third orange.

It allowed to prove some new general results about evolution of dynamical networks and their stability (strong synchrionization). These results allowed to formulate general simple principles:

1.It is easier to synchronize similar (close to each other in their characteristics) elements.

2.It is easier to synchronize smaller number of elements than larger networks consisting of such elements.

On the basis of these two principles were suggested concrete (principally new) topologies of networks which demonstrated in numerical experiments with networks of semiconductor lasers higher synchronizability than standard (e.g. all to all or fully connected networks) that were considered to be the best candidates for high synchronizability. There are no doubts that a general mathematical theory is applicable to much larger class of networks than just networks of semiconductor lasers.
